Posted: December 20, 2014
												This game is listed as Tower Defense game, but its less about defense and more about pushing a wave back to its source.Essentially your enemy isn't a monster, a beast, a beam of light... its water (this game calls it creep) and in order to stop creep from extending you have to push it back and turn off the faucet. Your enemy has no path, it goes from high to low, and can be channeled like a river or as even as a ocean.Is it the best defense game you've never heard of... ITS NOT A DEFENSE GAME ITS AN ASSAULT GAME. Your not fighting to stay alive... your fighting to stop the expansion of your opponent any means necesary.Story is ok... its deep and enriching but if you want to ignore it you probably will.Gameplay is complicated, yet simple... just watch out for Farbor, if your a slow player you will not finish farborMusic is repetitive and generic... its like 4 tracks on autoplay. The sounds are mehReplayability? Do you like to play for time, play lots of maps, creator is very deep...

Posted: July 12, 2015
												You can check this out in video form here: 


YouTube™ Video: Game Spotlight: Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal 

			Views: 977		

			Creeper World 3 is what happens when cellular automata takes over a strategy simulation. Instead of discreet units that attack your base, a fluid-like substance spreads over the terraformable...		

Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal is a fluid time strategy game,that is a game where you can pause and even speed up the time, just like in city builder games.Creeper World 3 focuses heavily on base building. All buldings need to be connected to a resource network and many of the buildings can be moved in a way similar to the Terran buildings in StarCraft. The main enemy is the creeper, which is a fluid flowing out of emitters.This fluid will flow downhill which is usually towards you. You cannot build in creeper and it destroys your buildings if it touches them.The maps have 10 height levels and you can build terraformers to change the terrain gradually. This gives you tons of tactical options. The simplest example would be to build yourself a high wall as protection against the creeper. Beware that creeper levels accumulate and if you do not destroy some, it will flow over your precious walls.You have various guns and mortars in your arsenal to destroy the creeper and you can even deploy your own anti-creeper, but this is just pushing back against the endless flow. To stop new creeper from forming, you need to push towards the emitter and build a special building, the nullifier, and protect it until it powers up enough to destroy the emitter.There are other interesting foes and obstacles, which I will not spoil here. The bread and butter of the enemy is the creeper emitter. Most of the tension for me was usually in the early game, where I needed to stave off the creeper while building my resource economy and it's often about eeking out tiny little advantages until I could stably match the creeper. After that, the aggressive phase starts. There are dozens of interesting story missions with diverse leveldesigns where you need different strategies to win.After beating the story missions, which took me about 30 hours!, you have a sheer endless supply of challenge maps, as well as tons of user generated maps. Though I find that the challenge maps aren't as diverse as the story maps, so once you find your dominant strategy, they tend to play out similarly. Creeper World 3 is also an excellent podcast game, since all relevant information is presented visually.The game gets a clear purchase recommendation from me.You can play the demo version beforehand, you can find that on the developer's website.Creeper World 3 has a crazy high rating of 97% on Steam, which I think is because the Trailer shows you exactly what you can expect from the game.

Posted: August 11, 2015
												Creeper World 3 is very similar to Creeper World 1. For those who haven't played Creeper World 1:You need to build and defend a little city from a relentless flow of blue goo whose physics behaves like water. You can vaporize it with lasers, blow it up with mortars, hit it with air strikes, and even terraform the landscape to trap it--for a while. The catch is that all of these things require energy, and you've got to find a balance between building up your energy supply while also building up your defenses. If you don't have enough of one or the other, the never-ending flow of creeper will slowly overwhelm your city. It's an excellent strategy game that combines defensive thinking and resource management.For those who have played CW1:This is mostly the same game, but with a story-mode and plenty of new levels. There's also a few new toys to play with, like ways to generate your own "anti-creeper," ways to terraform the terrain, and even ways to fly energy packets to remote areas that are not connected to your network. The creeper also has a few new tricks including "digitalis" which spreads faster and is harder to destroy but is limited to pre-defined paths, and "runners" which are little mobs that can temporarily disable your structures. I could knock the game for not being more innovative, but I liked CW1 enough that I thoroughly enjoyed having a similar experience again.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												Probably the best game that I've played this year! Bought it while it was on sale, and it turned out to be something that I'd pay the full price and would still get way over content/cent I'd get from most other titles.+ The variety of units is just enough for the game to always have a choice of what to do next and how to complete particular map.+ Rather interesting story mode, followed by tons of randomly generated maps, AND some really challenging ones made by alpha testers.+ Map generator - even more content!+ Map creator and user-created maps.- Only one song for the entire game, playing on every level. It's quite long, dynamic and really great, and takes really long to get old, but after 60+ hours I wish there was more music.- Game really has only a couple ways to challenge you - Creeper and Digitalis with Runners. Most of the challenge comes from the map itself. Some story and player maps have very diverse objectives and obstacles, so if you got bored, go to Alpha Sector or Colonial Space.- Some maps can take you up to 2 HOURS to complete!- If you are a completionist type of guy - good luck to you XD ! I doubt I'll ever complete any sector besides story one.Seriously, this game is awesome and you should buy it. If you like strategy games. that is.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												This is actually quite a good game, once you go through couple of the first missions. Through the campaign it keeps things fresh, throwing your way new challenges every time. And the best part is that it does not hold your hand. You can spend all the time you want in any mission and beat it in a way that works for you. It can be quite meditative experience. You can spend hours to build all the terrain to the highest level, and fill map with reactors, or not. And after you beat story mode there is a map editor and an endless amount of user-generated, auto-generated and other maps. So you can sink a ton of time in it. Price is good too, especially on sales.If you like tower defense games or something like Perimeter, you'll probably enjoy this game.The only problem I have with that game is its achievements. A lot of them are stupid, grindy or just unachievable. It is just too easy to cheat in that game if you want to do so. So leaderboards are filled with cheaters. If you don’t care about achievements just ignore this part.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												Creeper World might have the least appealing trailer ever; the presentation is unrefined at best.  Hoever, this is a true diamond in the rough.  Based on other reviews, it sounds like most folks share my opinion.  This game takes the best parts of the tower defence, real time strategy, and sim games and remixes them into something greater than the sum of its parts.  Throw an engaging narrative on top of that, and I am a happy gamer.  If you really aren't sure whether this game is for you, check out the online version... it started as a freely distributed browser game, and several early versions are still out there.

												I must say this game hides quite well behind apparent dated graphics and, let's be honest, pretty ugly UI. It grows on you however, as a long form strategy game unlike any other I've played before. I also found myself enticed by the story and the imagination therein. Some missions are challenging, but when you get past those hurdles you realise it's fair difficulty, and most of the time it's simply your build order that might need revising for that mission.It's somewhere between Total Annihilation and Starcraft. The only thing that really bothered me was the music.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												I always love a good genre-bendre and this one is interesting. Instead of just building towers along a route to mow down enemies, you build movable towers to gradually beat-back the spread of purple goop. You have to manage power and supply lines as well. Quite fun.Graphics aren't stellar but they don't need to be. Som games need to look good and some don't. FPS and other action-oriented games all almost always more fun if they look better. Some games don't benefit much from a visual upgrade.After playing more-recent shooters, it's really hard for me to play through (for example) Dark Forces. One of my favorite games of all time but it's such an eyesore that it's hard to play. CW3 could look as nice as Starcraft 2 but that wouldn't make it a better game; it would just make it a better-looking game.They could maybe charge a few extra dollars if it looked like SC2 but then I'd complain that it wasn't worth the price.Good game, CUSTOMIZABLE CONTROLS, fun (but skippable) story.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												I first saw this game, and thought it looked pretty stupid with it's color scheme, tiny, sporadic level design and seemingly "generic" style (I.E Strategy/Tower Defense-ish style building game just pumping out buildings).  Being open minded enough, and enjoying games like this anyways however, I threw it on my wish list, to revisit when it was on sale.  And boy was I glad I bought it, becoming one of my more quick favorites, moving up the list of a steam game I've purchased and actually played, beyond the title screen that is.  It's fast paced, with a pause button, and simple in terms of building order and/or layouts, but complex in the ways you can go about beating one level to the next.  It has a lot of advanced features, that aren't really necessary to win, but awesome when you figure out ways to utilize them (turning off building re-supply or disarming buildings temporarily).  The only downside I've found with this game so far, is that it's kind of challenging in a linear sort of way, meaning if you don't know what you are doing the first time a new building is introduced you can find yourself suddenly losing after playing a level for 30 minutes, which kinda sucks.  If you aren't sure of the buildings function or influence on the given level you sort of have to resort to trial and error a few times to figure out how to win.  However, that is the only flaw I have with the game so far, and it's a small one at that, as it is fun, challenging without being stupidly hard, and after a few times playing the visual style turns out to be perfectly fine.  Well worth the 15 bucks.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												The best game i have every played (i have about 50 hours in this game out side of steam) 1000000000000000000/10I would recommened it no matter the person even if you hate video games or have never played one yet (but play creeper world 3 abraxis or the demo first so you are familiar with the machanics)The actual review:Story: This game takes place 5 billion years after CR2, that's all the story for now because i don't want to spoil things.Gameplay: Every level except for the 2 systems leading to Prospector and Tormented zone, and the system which has Farbor in it introduces new mechanics. Such as Vapen which gives you your final command node, or Arca which gives you Thor. The gameplay is mainly build weapons to fight off various enemies and advance.The enemies are runners, spores, and the creeper. In addition to this you also have digitalists which can transport creeper over terrain instead of the creeper having to flow over. Many levels will introduce a new mechanic whether it's a permament enmy, a new tech, or a custom enemy, such as Ormos which has no emmiters, but creeper stuck in space and will come down once you land. Also on Ormos you get Terps whichcan terrraform the land. The terrian is in 10 levels. 1 being the lowest and 10 the highest, the previously mentioned digitalists can ignore this boundary and can jump terrain even if the emmiter strengh is at 3 (yes in the main campgain there are emmiters that emits 3 creeper every five seconds). You paint the terrian with whatever level you want it to be and the terps will slowly work on it. This can be sped up by a powerzone. The terps reqiure energy and the area they are terraforming cannot be covered with creeper. The powerzone enhanch all of your units abilities such as being able to make terps work faster and have a longer range or turning the motor into a fast firing, long range beast. The creeper is like CR1 so nothing to say there. However, the runners must be connected to digitalis to spawn and to survive. The runners will come out of runner nests and will stun your units, the best unit to kill them are snipers. The spores are like the ones in CR1 and CR2 they must be killed by beams and will drop a payload of creeper if not destroyed. The AE fields prevent your air units (guppys, bombers, and strafers) from flying over them. Your air units are guppys, bombers, and strafers. Guppys will transport  packets to your units such as AC, energy, or ore. Bombers use AC to spray down AC on an area and are the most powerful air unit. Strafers use energy and are essentually fighters. AC is short for anti-creeper and is gained from ore which comes from ore mines which can only be played on special spots or else you would win every mission too easily. There are 2 AC units, sprayers and bombers. Sprayers will spray AC that automatically fights creeper. It works like the AC from CR2 and it will protect your units if creeper hits them meaning that reactors will be safe if ac is on them. The main units are collecters, relays, reactors, blasters, motars, and nufflifiers. Collecters, will give you some energy and will expand you energy network, place these as far away from each other as possible since the energy production doesn't stack (they collect energy from an area like the ones from CR1). Reactors can be and should be placed in tight packs since they always give .4 energy, that can upgraded in the forge or using power nodes. Blasters have to have a line of sight and fire fast. Motars don't have to have a line of sight. Nuffelers can destory emmiters. The forge can upgrade things such as packet  speed, energy effifency, or weapon range (and yes move speed does apply to guppy's).  This review is getting very long and i covered most of the things i wanted to covers so now onto bugs.If you bugs in this game record a video, upload it to youtube, and send me the link.Oh and this game has maybe 30 story levels, 30-100 alpha levels (levels that were made in the alpha) a random generator, close to a thousand user-made maps some of which allow you to play as the creeper, and 2 areas with thousands of levels which add a new mechanic in addition to the regular stuff and an extra credits mission which turns it into a third person shooter so maybe 10 or infinity hours of content for you to play until you get bored

Posted: June 19, 2015
												I hate to say it but Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal might have ruined me for all other Tower Defense-related games TT_TT The Tower Defense genre has become rigid and formulaic over the years, the core gameplay has become ridiculously arbitrary. CW3 has re-introduced a sense of urgency to the core gameplay of the genre, in a fresh new way. Players of CW3 are only limited by their own creativity; I've barely scratch the surface of the single player campaign and I have already developed my very own unique way of strategizing and dealing with the Creeper.The depth of the core gameplay is intelligently designed and built, and the soundtrack is beautiful and albeit repetive, fits perfectly with the non-stop strategizing action. How will you approach the existential problem that is the Creeper? Stretch far and thin for some quick advantages, or build up a defense to nurture an unrelenting force against the ever-growing blue goop? You decide.5/5 Thumb up and yes, yes, yes.

Posted: April 19, 2015
												I've bought and played all variants of Creeper World, and this is the best one yet.It's very good at scratching the strategy, RTS, tower-defense itch.However, the nature of the enemy in most levels, essentially a corrosive liquid, combined with periodic balistic strikes, means that once you have built up your initial defense, you are effectively safe and need only expand your defensive line until you eliminate enemy towers/units. (Yes, I know there are other enemy-types besides the two mentioned above, but none that show up mid-game or late-game, to create dynamic havoc in your carefully laid plans.)There IS the concept of pre-existing barriers that corrode, giving a timed threat-release, but these are rarely employed to anything like the full potential of providing a mid-game threat. Even if they did, there is nothing that provides a late-game threat or reversal of fortunes, no increasing flood of more powerful foes, etc. There is no ramping up of the initial threat which might turn the tide if you don't deploy for it. Really, the only way to lose a game at the mid-point or toward the end is user error, like uncovering a flank with anti-missle defenses and having an attack get through to the rear. Even then, if it doesn't cut off significant supply lines, which can easily be made redundant, then the front-line may not be affected at all by the misfortune.But then... you can download fiendish levels that are user-made to solve that problem to a degree.8/10 (or relatively speaking, as fun and playable as any game in the Tower Defense genre available on Steam, if not more-so)

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game combines the best of tower defense and real-time strategy games into an immensely enjoyable and challenging experience that any fan of such genres can truly enjoy.You are given the task of creating defenses to repel the Creep. Which is basically a water-like substance that destroys all life. Your towers can shoot and repel the liquid as it gets close, but any lone tower can become swamped and overran by too much creep. So you need to strategize and plan how to best overcome your challenging situation in each mission.The campaign is fantastic, and the story that goes with it is even pretty cool, more than I expected out of a game I originally knew nothing about.If you are unsure of this game, play its predecessors for free, they are browser games, some of which are hosted on the developer's site, Knucklecracker.

												The difficulty ramps up dramatically! I loved how each new level seemed to introduce completely new ways to play the game, sometimes forcing you to dramatically change your playstyle. Posted: June 18, 2015
												The third game in the fantastic creeper world series. It takes the gameplay of the original, and builds on it; interestingly, it gives you all of your old toys pretty quickly. The anti-creeper from the sequel makes a return, and works quite well. The level design was decent, although there were times when I felt it could've used work, and I rarely found it necessary to use more than one control node, with the exception of the timed missions.The story was the weakest part, having reduced the cast to just two members: Abraxis and his ship's AI. There's some good world building, but I think it could've been greatly expanded upon, and the twist ending was really unexpected, and felt out of place. I'm not fond of stories that retcon their own history. If you want a great story, I'd recommend playing the original, which is still the best in this regard.I was honestly hoping for a longer experience overall, but there is replay value in the form of custom community maps (still haven't tried it yet), as well as a random map generator which need to be unlocked through the campaign. Something I'd love to see is a massive map, spanning several screens in size, with complex terrain and hidden secrets buried around the map; the only time you excavate anything in game is during the last level.On the whole, fans of the genre will enjoy this, just don't expect any literary awards. 8/10.

Posted: January 6, 2016
												A deceptively engrossing and story-rich tower defense that's not exactly a tower defense. Build nodes, manage power, and strategize against a fluid antagonist in increasing levels of complexity. New node types, enemy types, mechanics, and environmental factors get introduced at a steady trickle, alongside a sci-fi storyline rife with mystery and intrigue. If you're the type to like TD games and are looking for something fresh, unique, and has a lot of depth, this game is a must buy -- especially if it goes on 80%+ off sales.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												This game is wonderful. I bought it a long time ago and thought I'd try it out yesterday. My goodness, this is an amazing game. I've only cleared 3 star systems, but I have thoroughly enjoyed how this game had me looking at my clock, realizing I have work to do, but still wanted to complete "one more level."This game combines tower defense mechanics and your traditional real time strategy games where you are on the frontal assault. You create power systems, linked together a supply grid you create, adding weapons structures and such to fight back the creeping enetity, creeper. It combines wonderful elements of strategic challenge and planning, since the creeper is constantly spreading toward you and your base, you often have to act fast to set up power facillities and defenses before you can press forward. I haven't found it terribly difficult so far. I have a habit of using more energy than I can produce before I spam reactors (need to work on that). I enjoy how each level throws new mechanics to aid and threaten you further. But otherwise, this game has been a wonderful rentry for me into a genre (RTS) I have driffted away from over the years.10/10 would have my base blown up by spores again.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												I always love a good genre-bendre and this one is interesting. Instead of just building towers along a route to mow down enemies, you build movable towers to gradually beat-back the spread of purple goop. You have to manage power and supply lines as well. Quite fun.Graphics aren't stellar but they don't need to be. Som games need to look good and some don't. FPS and other action-oriented games all almost always more fun if they look better. Some games don't benefit much from a visual upgrade.After playing more-recent shooters, it's really hard for me to play through (for example) Dark Forces. One of my favorite games of all time but it's such an eyesore that it's hard to play. CW3 could look as nice as Starcraft 2 but that wouldn't make it a better game; it would just make it a better-looking game.They could maybe charge a few extra dollars if it looked like SC2 but then I'd complain that it wasn't worth the price.Good game, CUSTOMIZABLE CONTROLS, fun (but skippable) story.

Posted: December 5, 2015
												Good game. I was quickly hooked on the campaign but then I got to Tormented Space which seemed impossible. I went to the prospector zone and it had many planets that were all too easy until I ran across Molreport which again was impossible. Seems like the planets are either too easy or impossible once you finish the short campaign which ends without a word of explanation. I have only seen a small fraction of the Arc Eternal universe so I don't know if there are going to be more challenging planets. I'm beginning to think that like most games that rely on user created maps, that there is a lot of tedium. You'll have to look hard to find challenging games once you finish the short campaign. There isn't a lot of variety in the buildings. If you zoom in close there isn't anything to see. There isn't much in the way of detailed tool tips. That's too bad because specific information could make a difference. I enjoyed terraforming my way into enemy territory but building shields is faster and less complicated. You just build millions of generators and then shield your way into the deep stuff and rip out the bad things by the roots. Bombers, straffers and guppies are there but they are rather tedious and much less effective. I didn't see people putting up lots of experience nodes to capture that might encourage you to level up your ore and AC carrying capacity in order to launch a big D day type invasion. I would highly recomend this game at the sale price especially if the professional types are going to build a longer campaign that is as delightful as their earlier campaign but this is not up there in quality like Mount and Blade or Kerbal Space Program. If their mission was to show those corporate types that they could do as good a job as any big studio, they didn't succeed. If Stardock is the MacDonalds of gaming then these guys are the Chinese takeout that opened on the corner with the crispy vegetables, delicious sauces and suspiciously slippery meat.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												One of those 'great anytime' sort of games. Campaign, random gen maps, many different strategies to win with, pacing you can choose in most maps. If you ever liked games where you are constantly fighting the horde, this is an RTS that takes that concept to the core. Here the horde isn't zombies or aliens, here it is a gelatinous fluid that spreads at a constant rate from various emittors. That is it. Shoot it, blow it up, build up walls to contain it or protect yourself with, it will eventually flood the map higher than the highest mountains if you do not stem the tide. It is relentless. This game tickles a specific 'kill the horde' thing I have in my head every now and then and does so in a memorable way. I already have plenty of time in the non-Steam version before unlocking it on Steam, I'm playing on here simply to gather achievements on top of playing normally but I'm not playing specifically for the achievements. This game is simply a great time-filler between other games, like right now I'm bored of various FPS's and RTS's in my library and just want some straight up fun. Not too simple, not overly complex, the graphics are functional and have their own aesthetic I appreciate. Don't see it go on sale often but even full price I got my money's worth with several dozen hours in already on the non-Steam version. It also runs on Linux. What else can you ask for?

												100/10This is the best strategy game I have played in ages. It has a unique idea, it's well thought through and brilliantly executed. The whole game is a slow build against the liquid-like enemy, and as such is difficult to lose. Instead you'll find yourself stuck trying to figure out how to push forward in certain scenarios, or overwhelmed before you can get a foothold on your position. The story is nothing special, mostly just flavour text to give some kind of structure to the missions, but the game itself has been put together so well that you'll forget they even thought they needed a story. Posted: September 12, 2015
												(Before edit, play time was 150-170 hours)You get one very nice campain.The game has an integrated map editor and you can play the custom maps made by other players.There are also two areas with lots of auto-generated maps, some of them very difficult and few of them impossible.I recomend the campain for those who like tower defense and strategy games.I recomend the extremly difficult maps for those who like to discover alone how to improve and optimize.I have not played yet any of the player made maps, so I can tell little about them. I know that you can use scripts and custom images when you create the maps so possibly the comunity maps might be interesting too. You can rate those too and I seen a thriving comunity there :)Edit:(08-Oct-2015) Play time: 209 hoursI made two maps, a normal map and one with scrips.The programming language used in scrips is based on "reverse polish notation" concept: - you put the values into the stack and the operand afterward on top of them- the operand will combine the top elements (these are consumed)- the result is being placed back to the top of the stackThe concept is very different from normal programming languages. They say on the wiki that you do not have to be a programmer to learn this language.I say this is true for any programming language. And after you learn it, you are a programmer. Not an experienced or profesional one, but a programmer nevertheless.Regarding the maps: I made them for myself, as hard as possible. Some people do not like hard maps.I will continue occasionally to make maps inbetween other games.I avoid playing custom maps to avoid being influenced by their ideas.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												A simple yet amazingly versatile concept: Build against goo.In Creeper World 3 you take command of an automated base that gathers energy and ore and uses it to supply a diversity of weapons and utility tools, such as terraforming, to survive an seemingly endless onslaught of an oozy, purple substance called "Creeper".Much like the Creeper that some of you know form Starcraft, this slow flood will damage your buildings.In order to obtain, hold or destory a range of objectives, you will have to protect your base by clever build defences, until it provides enough energy to conquer and scrub-free new land. New land means new buildingspace and more energy and the circle repeats till victory.The strong side of this strategy puzzle game is, that the way you expand is totally up to you.Artillery and dropping additional bases is my recommended tactic.It is not an easy game.Players of Starcraft or similar micro/macro skill based RTS games will probably enjoy the level of APM that is needed to hunt the online highscores in this game.Apart from being a challenging and fun strategy and puzzle game, Creeper World also has an own storyline.A space captain and an ancient AI take on a seemingly hopeless battle against an alien race that teleports emitters of Creeper onto every planet which ever existed. As they try to understand the relentless hatred of their alien adversaries, the duo of lone survivors discovers a conspiracy that seems to be encoded into the very fabric of the universe itself.It tends to stretch dialogues to create tention, which works but is a bit exhausting. Also the characters are aggressively unaware of the mysteries that surround them. But perhaps that's just me.

Posted: October 12, 2015
												This is possibly one of my favorite games in my library. I get bored with games very easily, but this is one of the few that I can spend hours in and never even notice the time. The campaign itself has hours upon hours of gameplay, not to mention the extra level packs and the hundreds upon thousands of fan-made levels. This game is well worth the price. The Creeper World series has always drawn me back again and again and it never disappoints everytime I plant my command center and begin the battle against that awful blue goop.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												Ignore the play time reported by Steam... I bought this game direct from the developer's website and played it for quite a while before activating it on Steam.  Plus, if you consider the first two games and the free versions on Kongregate, I've easily logged a hundred hours or more in the whole series.I'm not a huge fan of tower defense or RTS, but this game combines the two genres in a way that is incredibly fun.  The basic plot is that a "grey-goo" type of substance, called the Creeper, has taken over the galaxy, and it's up to you to fight back.  You plop down a Command Node, build a few Collectors to generate energy, and try to keep from being overwhelmed until you can build up enough to go on the offensive.  However, there is enough variation in the game mechanics that each map presents a new challenge and a new puzzle to solve.There is one map (anyone who's played the game long enough will know the one I'm talking about) that really ruins the fun and actually put me off the game for a long while.  Unlike the others where you can take your time and develop whatever strategy you want, this one is a timed mission and a pretty tough one at that.  So consider yourself warned...But otherwise, an absolute joy to play and definitely a strong addition to your library.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												The Flash games were amazingly fun to play, and when I bought CW3:AE, I thought it would be nothing more than an expansion of Abraxis Stimulant. I wasn't expecting many new features, and not many more were added, but this was fine. What CW3:AE did add, however, was an incredibly entertaining campaign, a fully fleshed-out map editor, a fascinating overarching story, and an experience that, although relatable to Abraxis Stimulant, felt completely refreshing and fun. If you haven't played the flash games, I certainly reccomend playing those first, and playing those first certainly impacts a player's skills within the game. However, AE did an amazing job of ensuring that all players will be able to enjoy the game, reguardless of experience in the previous games.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												I first saw this game, and thought it looked pretty stupid with it's color scheme, tiny, sporadic level design and seemingly "generic" style (I.E Strategy/Tower Defense-ish style building game just pumping out buildings).  Being open minded enough, and enjoying games like this anyways however, I threw it on my wish list, to revisit when it was on sale.  And boy was I glad I bought it, becoming one of my more quick favorites, moving up the list of a steam game I've purchased and actually played, beyond the title screen that is.  It's fast paced, with a pause button, and simple in terms of building order and/or layouts, but complex in the ways you can go about beating one level to the next.  It has a lot of advanced features, that aren't really necessary to win, but awesome when you figure out ways to utilize them (turning off building re-supply or disarming buildings temporarily).  The only downside I've found with this game so far, is that it's kind of challenging in a linear sort of way, meaning if you don't know what you are doing the first time a new building is introduced you can find yourself suddenly losing after playing a level for 30 minutes, which kinda sucks.  If you aren't sure of the buildings function or influence on the given level you sort of have to resort to trial and error a few times to figure out how to win.  However, that is the only flaw I have with the game so far, and it's a small one at that, as it is fun, challenging without being stupidly hard, and after a few times playing the visual style turns out to be perfectly fine.  Well worth the 15 bucks.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												One of the best tower defenses I have ever played. Having played Creeper World and Creeper World 2, this follows the game design of the former. While the graphics may be on a lower end than that of normal games, it provides hours and hours of fantastic gameplay.For newbies. game elements are introduced to you slowly through the storyline, all the way up to the boss map (hello Thor!). The storyline does build off CW1 and CW2, so you might be a bit lost in understanding any plot and twists. Recommendation to play the first two iterations first - they are both great games.The game allows you to freely tab out (I'm looking at you Popcap) while remaining in play, and you are able to micromanage and rearrange your defenses when paused - a definite plus. You also get multiple save slots! The speed up buttons are also a wonderful addition - anyone that has played tower defenses will appreciate speed up buttons (1x, 2x, 3x and 4x). Plus point is that all your games are cloud saved on Steam - no more having to rebeat the entire storymap and more when you change a new computer or accidentally clear your files! The Alpha and Prospector sector are two such additions which will provide an eternity more of gameplay once you finish storymode. The maps are heavily varied, ranging from small maps to huge maps - all of which will require different strategies. It doesn't feel like you're merely doing the same thing over and over again. And if you ever finish the abovementioned sectors (has anyone?!), there are plenty more user-made levels for you to try out.An average map generally ranges about 15 - 25 minutes to win. It's a great game to play in between other games for a short break or while waiting for queue times. For only SGD15.00, easily worth every single cent. 10/10

Posted: August 10, 2016
One of the best strategy games on SteamMany survival/strategy games are like drowning. Such games play out as a constant desperate struggle to stay above water, with no chance to breathe, until you are eventually overwhelmed and die a horrible death.Creeper World 3 is more like walking a tight-rope. At any time you can pause, catch your breath, and steady yourself for the next step. The risk is when you start moving. It is always a delicate balance - if you go too fast and overextend yourself, you will lose ground instead of gaining it. This is strategy at its best.If drowning sounds like more fun, don't play this game - it isn't for you.The diverse selection of units - each with its own distinct role - enables several rewarding strategies. The level terrain and enemy placement strongly impact tactics, so every mission feels distinct.The game includes more missions than you will ever play, a level editor for making even more missions and sharing with the community, and an option for procedurally-generated levels as well. You will never run out of content.Creeper World 3 features satisfying and refreshing mechanics you will find in no other game. My first experience with it was overwhelmingly enjoyable. As I mastered the mechanics, it felt less novel but no less satisfying. Years later, I still dedicate time every month to purging more creeper.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												i pondered the question of whether this game gets my recommendation or not for some time. this is how i broke it down.this game is a 2D top down tower defence game, like the literally billions of games out there. the thing is: a) does anything make this game stand out from the crowd and b) is it fun?the story is told in text boxes between you and your onboard AI, in this day and age i find this is kinda lazy and must admit some of the early story i just ignored, if i wanted to read the story constantly id play Final Fantasy 7 or earlier.obviously as the game progresses you get an array of different weapons of which to fight the Creeper...or purple gunk/liquid as i like to refer to it.the "enemy" just kinda oozes over the map at different rates depending on the map level, so it becomes a balance of power, expansion and defence,  missions can be won or lost by over reaching too soon or being impatient when waiting for power cores to be built, and power is essential.the game starts out quite easy but then becomes challenging in no time at all, indeed the game kicks you in the butt for any lapses of concentration.the graphics are really quite basic and the unit design is awful, indeed when you have straffers, bombers and then try to move stuff it all gets messy quite quickly. the maps can be anything from huge to tiny bringing their own challenges and/or rewards.the best weapon in game has to be the sprayer, it can create that all important safe zone to defend whilst you consolodate your base, However, they need Ore for ammo and that can be a massive issue on some maps. like i previously mentioned you can move your turrets and base around which actually is qute a fun gimic as it lets you make a rolling advance on the enemy or plug any gaps without waiting for new units.later maps allow you to build a forge for turret upgrades that affects turrets instantly (no need for further upgrade time) and Bertha guns that basically can wipe out your upgrade points in 1 shot for minimal return given the creeper can at times spawn super fast (the bertha fire Aether that you need for upgrades)(Spoiler)  and then on the last mission you get the Titan, a space ship that can shoot rockets etc but is pretty useless on the whole but essential for the last mission.all in all the game is challenging, and will punish the unprepared quite early, but saying that there is a map creator and a massive online community that designs maps for you to try, it also has a prospector zone whereby you can fight in over 100 maps for stuff or play other players maps in the Alpha zone so even after the story missions theres still hundreds of maps to play. a massive gripe i have with the game is the music, 1 track on a constant loop....wouldnt be so bad but it lasts like 5 mins and some maps can take over an hour to beat so you have to listen to it over and over again just to start all over again on the next map, another gripe is the ability to store your score per map online after each level, however the peeps at the top of the leader bored somehow managed to beat the map in like 35 seconds to score 9k points, yeah right...so ok for the fact the online community is there and theres an almost endless ability to play the different maps i'll give it a thumbs up. However i personally got bored quite quickly, the story is barely believable, the music drove me to distraction and theres no veriety really, another map, another ooze producing blob that needs to die rinse and repeat but then again thats the formula for every Tower defence game out there. the ability to move turrets is great but i dont know     if they pioneered this gimic.

Posted: March 26, 2015
												In my opinion, Creeper World 3 is more carefully crafted and more well-made than most big-budget games out there today, it truly is a show of how it isn't the budget that matters, it is simply how the game ends up being upon release.How was it on release? It was pretty good, having had it about a month after it was released on the Knucklecraker site, it was later released on Steam, and due to the Developer beign a really awesome person, Virgil allowed all previous owners of the game, to get a free steam key, since they'd already bought the game.So okay, I'm keepnig this one short.The game is basically a Tower Defense/Real-Time Strategy hybrid, where the enemy is not identical to you in any possible form. Your enemy is (as the store page itself says) a fluid-like substance that flows over the transformable terrain. This substance acts exactly like water, only if it touches your stuff, it either outright destroys it immediately (non weapon/titan units) or it slowly melts away at it (Weapons and titans).The substance flows from emitters, which you need to fight towards, and destroy them using Nullifiers, doing this as you go from world to world, saving them all from the Blue Tide named Creeper.Pros:- The Story is well-written honestly, keeping you guessing, even after you've beaten the story.- Unlike previous entries, you can use Titans, which are like superweapons, and they are awesome!- Also unlike previous entires, there are three endings insted of only one.- Each Story mission has many ways of beating it, there are those "Per map strategy that always wins" but no single strategy will get you a victory on every map.- The Environment actually means something in the game, allowing you to create fortresses for defense using terraforming, or for offense to get an easier shot at something, or even boxing in an emmitter.- The Soundtrack is by far the best I've ever fonud in the game. It perfectly fits the game's underlying post-apocalyptic setting set in the far future.- There are no bugs that are atleast in-game. It's never crashed, it's never frozen without external conflicts, it doesn't even have glitches.- You can make the Creeper any color if blue doesn't work. Red, Black, White, Purple... if it exists as a color, you can do it pretty much. Also works for anti-creeper too.- Literally thousands of levels to play after the story, with levels made by testers and part of the dev team like MadMag, the artist behind the game, or Virgil, all made with the game's own random map generator, the DMD, Dial Map Device.- Has the most impossible level ever put on a strategy game, Jovincoting, a map so hard, absolutely nobody has ever beaten it. This game has technically been out for about a couple years now. Or almost.- Strategy mostly consists of neat tricks you pick up along the way than actual builds as following a build will slow you down in almost every possible case, due to how maps are all different.- The Game has a map editor with it's own scripting language, using it can allow you to change the game form what it is, to a top down shooter (Credits mission), or even a game where you play as the creeper against AI-controlled enemy command nodes.Cons- The map selection music will often content ID youtube videos showing it.- I literally cannot think of anymore Cons. I've been trying to for the last two days.All of this and even more is only 17 dollars CDN, probly 15 US. Just get it, this game is basically one of the best, most underappreciated titles on the market today. A must buy for anyone who likes a good strategy game.

												First of all, don't be fooled by my playtime. I played the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game before the dev put it on Steam.This game takes the idea of a Tower Defense game, and completely reworks it:: -Where most Tower Defense games have a set path which is ridiculously easy to see, this one has a foe which is simply a liquid moving with the terrain, sometimes in unpredictable ways -Want to place that tower right next to where the enemy spawns? Well you will need to build a supply line reaching out to it -Wanting to just rush at the enemy spawners at top speed and destroy them? Better watch your energy reserves. You will run out quick if you aren't careful.The game even has a map generator in it which allows you to play any one of a ridiculous number of maps. And if you manage to complete all of those (Which would take so long to do, I don't know how you could...), there's still the high scores lists that allow you to compete with other players for the fastest level times.

												8/10. Excellent tower variation, map variation, and general enjoyment. See expanded below.Did you know this thing's earlier installments are available as flash games? That's how I first started playing th Creeper saga, and when I ran across this one on steam, I bought it without a second thought. That happened to be a great purchase that I have long enjoyed. In this game, you take on the role of the universes ultimate tower-defence gamer, protecting your command centers from an ever increasing biomass of pure evil long enough to extract data from the doomed planet and warp to the next system. The tower defence aspect of this game is great, with new weapons, reactos, and offensive technology unlocking progessively and adding more and more layers to the game as the difficulty ramps up.There is a story, which is what's driving you to keep playing missions: the promise of destroying the un-destroyable Creeper once and for all. Guided by a redoubtable A.I, your lone ship treks across the galaxy trying to unraval the mystery of the Creeper.Overall, a solid game. After the campaign is an endless array of maps, some dev made and countless other community made. The repetitivness of mission objectives can get boring,  but put it down and come back tomorrow and you'll keep having fun.

												(Before edit, play time was 150-170 hours)You get one very nice campain.The game has an integrated map editor and you can play the custom maps made by other players.There are also two areas with lots of auto-generated maps, some of them very difficult and few of them impossible.I recomend the campain for those who like tower defense and strategy games.I recomend the extremly difficult maps for those who like to discover alone how to improve and optimize.I have not played yet any of the player made maps, so I can tell little about them. I know that you can use scripts and custom images when you create the maps so possibly the comunity maps might be interesting too. You can rate those too and I seen a thriving comunity there :)Edit:(08-Oct-2015) Play time: 209 hoursI made two maps, a normal map and one with scrips.The programming language used in scrips is based on "reverse polish notation" concept: - you put the values into the stack and the operand afterward on top of them- the operand will combine the top elements (these are consumed)- the result is being placed back to the top of the stackThe concept is very different from normal programming languages. They say on the wiki that you do not have to be a programmer to learn this language.I say this is true for any programming language. And after you learn it, you are a programmer. Not an experienced or profesional one, but a programmer nevertheless.Regarding the maps: I made them for myself, as hard as possible. Some people do not like hard maps.I will continue occasionally to make maps inbetween other games.I avoid playing custom maps to avoid being influenced by their ideas.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												One of those 'great anytime' sort of games. Campaign, random gen maps, many different strategies to win with, pacing you can choose in most maps. If you ever liked games where you are constantly fighting the horde, this is an RTS that takes that concept to the core. Here the horde isn't zombies or aliens, here it is a gelatinous fluid that spreads at a constant rate from various emittors. That is it. Shoot it, blow it up, build up walls to contain it or protect yourself with, it will eventually flood the map higher than the highest mountains if you do not stem the tide. It is relentless. This game tickles a specific 'kill the horde' thing I have in my head every now and then and does so in a memorable way. I already have plenty of time in the non-Steam version before unlocking it on Steam, I'm playing on here simply to gather achievements on top of playing normally but I'm not playing specifically for the achievements. This game is simply a great time-filler between other games, like right now I'm bored of various FPS's and RTS's in my library and just want some straight up fun. Not too simple, not overly complex, the graphics are functional and have their own aesthetic I appreciate. Don't see it go on sale often but even full price I got my money's worth with several dozen hours in already on the non-Steam version. It also runs on Linux. What else can you ask for?

Posted: October 9, 2015
												One of the most fun and unique RTS/Tower defense games I've ever played. Basically, you're fighting a liquid. This liquid flows from higher elevation to lower elevation (like liquid does). There are emitters that pour this liquid out of them at specific intervals. You have several ways of corraling and destroying this liquid. Destroying thin liquid with laser turrets, deep liquid with mortars, or distant liquid with strafers. Corraling liquid with terraformers to lower or highten the terrain or shields that shove the liquid around. Or, even combinations of the two with anti-liquid that doesn't damage your towers and can destroy the bad liquid.There are several play-modes too. The campaign starts you off with very little unlocked and very easy missions. As it progresses, you unlock more turrets, learning what each does with the missions getting harder and harder. Eventually, you have nearly everything and the missions have reached alarming difficulty, requiring epic strategy to beat, making each mission defeated a great accomplishment and very satisfying.Colonial Space has a huge array of player created maps given ratings for each one with varying difficulties and extreme customization for each level.Alpha Sector is filled with misisons created by alpha testers of the game.Tormented Space and Prospector Zone have maps randomly generated by the engine.This game is all about strategy, and nothing to do with luck. Love it.I may be a little biased though, I've followed this series of games since the first. Creeper World was unique and amazing. Creeper World 2 was... okay, he took some aspects of the first one and made a different type of game that wasn't as well balanced nor built. But Creeper World 3 went back to the original gameplay of the first one, and he added many things to it, balanced it out, and made it a whole lot better.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												I whole-heartedly recommend this game. Fair warning: you will become addicted to it, and rack up 20 hours playing it in a  single week. I've played it over 10 hours in two *days*.The trailer, pictures, and even description on CW3's store page fail to do the game justice. It's RTS only in that you can place and move units while the timer is running. It's TD only in that your units only fire while sitting still, and half of your units can't move once placed. Allow me to paint you a different picture of this game. The creeper is like water that bubbles up from the ground, and you can't touch the water...because you're a cat with a lot of really cool turrets. Each of your turrets does something different. Half of your turrets aren't offensive devices; they're used to set up the infrastructure of your base, collecting resources, etc. Your energy recharges continuously, but your base can output more energy than it collects, and will eventually reach equillibrium with your input. When you start to net energy income, do you build more energy collectors, or new weapons? Eventually, you can terraform the map at large energy output, but you don't need the terraformers on constantly. Want a turret at a different location to combat the creeper? Your offensive turrets can fly. to new locations, but if your infrastructure hasn't caught up to the front, their ammo stores will drain rapidly.Each map is essentially a series of multi-step problems that can be solved in a variety of ways, especially as you unlock more turrets. Early in the game, it's pretty obvious what tactics the map maker had in mind, promarily because you haven't yet uinlocked all of the turrets. But not even half-way through the initial campaign, you come to understand the myriad paths you can take to solve each particular step of a problem. Terraforming is a big part of this: because you can literally change the shape of the map, setting up infrastructure one way opens up different solutions down the road.The two extremes of the spectrum of CW3 players are probably Speed Runners <----> Slow and Steady. I'm the latter right now, which is one of the reasons missions take me so long: I spend more than half the run-time with the timer paused. But you've got to be careful while paused: queue up too many turrets, and your production rapidly outpaces your income, slowing your entire system. The game doesn't punish you for being either kind of player--on most levels, your resources don't dwindle over time, so you could play a single map for hours in a trenchy-style of building one row of turrets just in front of your previous row. The game *does* punish you for not paying attention--being fast is definitely doable if your minimalistic solution has all of the right components. CW3 is a phenomenal example of the adage: gamers prefer good mechanics to good graphics. But don't let the 2D simplistic art scheme fool you. Not only are the mechanics solid, the performance stellar, but the interface is also straight-forward, and the controls seem pretty intuitive. Left-click to select, right-click-hold to move around the map. Zoom in/out with mouse wheel. Escape to un-select or exit out of a selection. The visuals and animations tell you what you need to know, and if something isn't working like you expected, it's pretty easy to figure out why.I wouldn't say it's a difficult game in the initial campaign, but it *is* intense regardless of your strategy. There appear to be scads of maps that the community has created that will test your skills, as will the Challenge section by the developers, *and* the custom-level editor is built right into the frakking game.Geez...I haven't even gotten to the Titans yet....  :}

Posted: January 1, 2015
												This is a gem of a strategy game. It's a RTS Tower defense-esque game, this might not sound like a good idea, but it works beautifully. There are two main mechanics that I will address:1. The Creeper. This is your enemy, it's a liquid entity that creeps forward from spawners, slowly covering more and more of the stage. You need to build towers to fight it back, and in turn advance farther along the stage yourself. Creeper would be very difficult to deal with if it didn't obey the laws of physics. Basically, in order for creeper to overflow onto a higher level of terrain, it has to have nowhere else to go on its current level. This leads to some fairly interesting placements, like a very powerful spawner at the bottom of a deep crater. There are plenty of other enemies too, runners and digitalis namely. Runners just run along digitalis and need to be destroyed with sniper towers, they can't directly destroy your towers, but can stun them long enough for creeper to overflow onto them. Digitalis is a kind of grid-like enemy that conducts creeper and prevents towers from being built, trust me, it's more difficult than it sounds.2. The Network. This game has parallels to a tower defense game, but calling it one doesn't do it justice. The biggest conventional differences being: Towers are networked, they have to be connected to your base to function; Towers can be moved freely, even off the network, albeit with limited ammo; towers use energy, constantly.The biggest difference as I stated is the network. You have to build collectors and relays between towers to provide pathways for the "packets" of which there are three types, ammo, construction, and totem. This means you can't just build towers in the most strategic spots right away, you have to build out to them, often fighting tooth and nail to get to them. Additionally, these packets cost energy, which is distributed evenly between the active types of packets, energy is obtained through collectors, which collect energy across an area, and reactors. Collectors gain no benefit from overlapping area and should be spread out, they are also one of the main staples in your network of towers. If you get too ambitious with your expansion, you'll enter energy starvation, where packets are produced less efficiently and you run the risk of your blasters running out of ammo and the line being pushed back.Between the campaign mode and the hundreds of other levels in the game + fan made ones, you could get hundreds of hours out of this game (I didn't because I just played creeper world 1 and 2 before it and was done after the campaign). Having played all three games, this is the best. Even at full price, I think you'll get your money's worth, this is a difficult game, you will need to think strategically and act quickly. It's a refreshing change of pace from most RTS and tower defense games in my opinion.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												One of the best tower defenses I have ever played. Having played Creeper World and Creeper World 2, this follows the game design of the former. While the graphics may be on a lower end than that of normal games, it provides hours and hours of fantastic gameplay.For newbies. game elements are introduced to you slowly through the storyline, all the way up to the boss map (hello Thor!). The storyline does build off CW1 and CW2, so you might be a bit lost in understanding any plot and twists. Recommendation to play the first two iterations first - they are both great games.The game allows you to freely tab out (I'm looking at you Popcap) while remaining in play, and you are able to micromanage and rearrange your defenses when paused - a definite plus. You also get multiple save slots! The speed up buttons are also a wonderful addition - anyone that has played tower defenses will appreciate speed up buttons (1x, 2x, 3x and 4x). Plus point is that all your games are cloud saved on Steam - no more having to rebeat the entire storymap and more when you change a new computer or accidentally clear your files! The Alpha and Prospector sector are two such additions which will provide an eternity more of gameplay once you finish storymode. The maps are heavily varied, ranging from small maps to huge maps - all of which will require different strategies. It doesn't feel like you're merely doing the same thing over and over again. And if you ever finish the abovementioned sectors (has anyone?!), there are plenty more user-made levels for you to try out.An average map generally ranges about 15 - 25 minutes to win. It's a great game to play in between other games for a short break or while waiting for queue times. For only SGD15.00, easily worth every single cent. 10/10

												This game is listed as Tower Defense game, but its less about defense and more about pushing a wave back to its source.Essentially your enemy isn't a monster, a beast, a beam of light... its water (this game calls it creep) and in order to stop creep from extending you have to push it back and turn off the faucet. Posted: March 26, 2015
												In my opinion, Creeper World 3 is more carefully crafted and more well-made than most big-budget games out there today, it truly is a show of how it isn't the budget that matters, it is simply how the game ends up being upon release.How was it on release? It was pretty good, having had it about a month after it was released on the Knucklecraker site, it was later released on Steam, and due to the Developer beign a really awesome person, Virgil allowed all previous owners of the game, to get a free steam key, since they'd already bought the game.So okay, I'm keepnig this one short.The game is basically a Tower Defense/Real-Time Strategy hybrid, where the enemy is not identical to you in any possible form. Your enemy is (as the store page itself says) a fluid-like substance that flows over the transformable terrain. This substance acts exactly like water, only if it touches your stuff, it either outright destroys it immediately (non weapon/titan units) or it slowly melts away at it (Weapons and titans).The substance flows from emitters, which you need to fight towards, and destroy them using Nullifiers, doing this as you go from world to world, saving them all from the Blue Tide named Creeper.Pros:- The Story is well-written honestly, keeping you guessing, even after you've beaten the story.- Unlike previous entries, you can use Titans, which are like superweapons, and they are awesome!- Also unlike previous entires, there are three endings insted of only one.- Each Story mission has many ways of beating it, there are those "Per map strategy that always wins" but no single strategy will get you a victory on every map.- The Environment actually means something in the game, allowing you to create fortresses for defense using terraforming, or for offense to get an easier shot at something, or even boxing in an emmitter.- The Soundtrack is by far the best I've ever fonud in the game. It perfectly fits the game's underlying post-apocalyptic setting set in the far future.- There are no bugs that are atleast in-game. It's never crashed, it's never frozen without external conflicts, it doesn't even have glitches.- You can make the Creeper any color if blue doesn't work. Red, Black, White, Purple... if it exists as a color, you can do it pretty much. Also works for anti-creeper too.- Literally thousands of levels to play after the story, with levels made by testers and part of the dev team like MadMag, the artist behind the game, or Virgil, all made with the game's own random map generator, the DMD, Dial Map Device.- Has the most impossible level ever put on a strategy game, Jovincoting, a map so hard, absolutely nobody has ever beaten it. This game has technically been out for about a couple years now. Or almost.- Strategy mostly consists of neat tricks you pick up along the way than actual builds as following a build will slow you down in almost every possible case, due to how maps are all different.- The Game has a map editor with it's own scripting language, using it can allow you to change the game form what it is, to a top down shooter (Credits mission), or even a game where you play as the creeper against AI-controlled enemy command nodes.Cons- The map selection music will often content ID youtube videos showing it.- I literally cannot think of anymore Cons. I've been trying to for the last two days.All of this and even more is only 17 dollars CDN, probly 15 US. Just get it, this game is basically one of the best, most underappreciated titles on the market today. A must buy for anyone who likes a good strategy game.

												Good game. I was quickly hooked on the campaign but then I got to Tormented Space which seemed impossible. I went to the prospector zone and it had many planets that were all too easy until I ran across Molreport which again was impossible. I have only seen a small fraction of the Arc Eternal universe so I don't know if there are going to be more challenging planets. I'm beginning to think that like most games that rely on user created maps, that there is a lot of tedium. You'll have to look hard to find challenging games once you finish the short campaign. There isn't a lot of variety in the buildings. If you zoom in close there isn't anything to see. There isn't much in the way of detailed tool tips. That's too bad because specific information could make a difference. I enjoyed terraforming my way into enemy territory but building shields is faster and less complicated. You just build millions of generators and then shield your way into the deep stuff and rip out the bad things by the roots. Bombers, straffers and guppies are there but they are rather tedious and much less effective. I didn't see people putting up lots of experience nodes to capture that might encourage you to level up your ore and AC carrying capacity in order to launch a big D day type invasion. I would highly recomend this game at the sale price especially if the professional types are going to build a longer campaign that is as delightful as their earlier campaign but this is not up there in quality like Mount and Blade or Kerbal Space Program. If their mission was to show those corporate types that they could do as good a job as any big studio, they didn't succeed. If Stardock is the MacDonalds of gaming then these guys are the Chinese takeout that opened on the corner with the crispy vegetables, delicious sauces and suspiciously slippery meat.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Ok. Creeper World 3 is an amazing RTS. You need to build your base, collect resources and build defences to protect yourself against the overwhelming enemy that quickly grows in power and takes over the whole map. When you grow strong enough, you start pushing back, shooting your way through the enemy forces. You need to make sure that your assault is well covered, is connected to the supply line and that you won't run out of resources at a critical moment. You shoot down air units and lauch air assaults and bombarding deep in enemy territory. Oh, and NEVER forget about defending your land. A small mistake can be enough to screw up your plans.It's extremely satisfying when you capture land and push further into the enemy territory, and destroy they structures. The game combines moments of despair, heroism and triumph. But there's one important detail.You don't fight humans, but blue alien mass that spreads extremely fast and destroys everything in it's path. But despite this you still feel like you fight a war against a much stronger enemy.The amount of different things you need to keep track off, the gameplay focused on tactical planning, the awesome music that's both dramatic and badass...Oh, and did I mention the crazy amount of content? There are thousands of maps you can fight on in the official campaigns, and there's also a level editor and a random level generator.In short: great RTS with a truckload of content. Buy it now.

												One of my all time favourite games. Probably the most original and replayable tower defense out there. Single player it can stand tall together with strategy games like starcraft or age of empires without shame. 100% achievments took me 450 hours. I suppose it can be done in half that time. There are tons more content even after the achievements. The biggest problem is probably how the ruleset is almost identical on every map.Suggestions for the creator. Posted: July 22, 2016
 TL:DR	 - It's a good strategy game, well polished with few issues if any, and it's quite fun, it's worth the money, and will offer many hours of gameplay with thousands of missions to choose from, including player made missions.This game is very much worth both the money spent buying it and the time spent playing it. It is a major time sink, hours go by without me even noticing. There's hundreds, even thousands of different maps and missions to choose from.Personally my favourite section is the player made custom maps and missions, they feature many different scenarios and events, even some new things not present in the base game like new units and new enemies. It's really great seeing all these things people have made, there's strategic maps people have made where you have to plan ahead and think carefully, wacky maps that are fun and light hearted, play as creeper maps where the role is reversed and you are the creeper assaulting a base, custom scenarios of different kinds made by people, it's all varied and quite fun to play.Another feature is a random map generator, where you put in the features you want, like map size, terrain type, and other variables, and the generator will create a random map based on what you want from it. For people who want a challenge, there's a section of the game dedicated to randomly made extremely difficult maps, some of which are literally impossible, others close to that. Most of them can be done, but they require a lot of thought and careful action to get there. For people who want a more casual experience there's a section dedicated to easier maps that have items called "artifacts of Odin", and the goal is to collect these items scattered throughout the various planets. There's also a campaign which features some interesting levels which teach you the game, some of which are quite tricky.The premise is that there's this entity called the creeper, that has been ravaging the universe for a long time. It spreads from planet to planet, creeping across like a liquid, and it is your job to simultaneously put up a strong defence to hold back the tide and to also effectively assault the source of this enemy. It's a cross between a tower defence, real time strategy and management sim all in one. You have to position your units, manage supply lines, organise your base, respond to the changes of the battle, manage your resources, extend out in an effort to attack whilst at the same time making sure your defences will hold. You have to be careful with what you do and choose a playstyle, do you turtle up, building up a strong defence capable of weathering the incoming assault at the cost of allowing the creeper to multiply thus causing future expansion to be slower, or do you reach out early for a preemtive strike, weakening the creeper early or gaining a strong foothold, at the risk of overextending and leaving gaps or weaker parts of your defence? There are different ways of playing this all depending on your own individual playstyle and what is better for the map you are playing.You can play this at your own pace, there's the option to play it at normal speed, 2X, 3X or 4X speed, and you can also pause the game and issue orders whilst paused, useful for assessing the situation on a large map where a lot of things are happening at once and you need to be controlling the battlefield in all these areas simultaneously.In terms of stability, this game is very stable, there's few bugs (I'm not even sure I've noticed any), it runs well and doesn't require high specs. It's a lot better in this regard than many big name titles made by whole studios, and this was afaik made by one person. There's a fair amount of UI options and a few graphical options which are all quite nice to have.

												8/10. Excellent tower variation, map variation, and general enjoyment. See expanded below.Did you know this thing's earlier installments are available as flash games? That's how I first started playing th Creeper saga, and when I ran across this one on steam, I bought it without a second thought. That happened to be a great purchase that I have long enjoyed. In this game, you take on the role of the universes ultimate tower-defence gamer, protecting your command centers from an ever increasing biomass of pure evil long enough to extract data from the doomed planet and warp to the next system. The tower defence aspect of this game is great, with new weapons, reactos, and offensive technology unlocking progessively and adding more and more layers to the game as the difficulty ramps up.There is a story, which is what's driving you to keep playing missions: the promise of destroying the un-destroyable Creeper once and for all. Guided by a redoubtable A.I, your lone ship treks across the galaxy trying to unraval the mystery of the Creeper.Overall, a solid game. After the campaign is an endless array of maps, some dev made and countless other community made. The repetitivness of mission objectives can get boring,  but put it down and come back tomorrow and you'll keep having fun.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												Creeper World. (This is a review for the trilogy which you can get through links on the developers website for about $25 and includes a Steam key for the third game, which is the only game currently on Steam)The Creeper World trilogy are RTS games, with a twist. The enemy is not (most of the time,) a specific unit, but instead a wave of blue goo that must be held/pushed back in order to achieve your goals. There are enemy units later on in the second and third games, but every level will be about beating the goo to some extent. The feel of the game is somewhat similar to a tower defense game at times, but not so constrained. Most of your 'units' are emplacements/turrets, albeit ones that can usually be moved when you need them somewhere else. The complexity of the game increases throughout the series, (so I would recommend starting weith the first game and playing through the trilogy,) but never felt stale even in the first game. The second game changed the style of the game somewhat, and whilst interesting and fun, it wasnt as engaging as the first game, and fortunately the third game returns to the style of the first. Dont get me wrong though, all three games are good. There is a story, but its a minimal affair, a paragraph or two at the start of each mission, sufficient to add a bit of colour, but ultimately nothing to get excited about. There are also downloadable demos for each game available on the developers website if you want to have a go and see for yourself. http://knucklecracker.com/ including a web based version of the first game.So, any drawbacks? The graphics are simplistic but functional, the same is probably true of the sound effects/music. but I tend to turn it off and listen to a cd anyway. The interface is a bit basic, could do with a bit of love and a bit more control, ie text sizes etc, but other than that, its an RTS and its a good one, with map editors, a lot of missions built in and literally thousands of player generated maps too. As such, it is absolutely recommended.

												A deceptively engrossing and story-rich tower defense that's not exactly a tower defense. Build nodes, manage power, and strategize against a fluid antagonist in increasing levels of complexity. New node types, enemy types, mechanics, and environmental factors get introduced at a steady trickle, alongside a sci-fi storyline rife with mystery and intrigue. If you're the type to like TD games and are looking for something fresh, unique, and has a lot of depth, this game is a must buy -- especially if it goes on 80%+ off sales.

Posted: May 11, 2016
												Absolutely love it.  This company released essentially a demo on Kongregate that had 10 free levels (I think it's called "Abraxis") that give you a rapid ascent through the upgrades and towers and such, and I would've been happy with just a continuation or something similar.  What I got was so much more.  It's a nice hybrid of an RTS and Tower Defense style, but it plays VERY differently than any other TD or RTS you've played.  Instead of an advancing army or lines of creeps, you get a rapidly encroaching liquid that floods the map and destroys your stuff, and that's the FIRST encounter, because it doesn't stop there.  Spore towers, anti-air towers, and many more weapons for the Creeper to attack you, all with a somewhat dull, but sorta interesting story behind many dead civilizations.  Almost every main-storyline level has something COMPLETELY new and different to it, making you change your play style to work with it, and the extra modes you unlock add even more.  Prospector mode is EXACTLY what I wanted.  Is it repetative?  Can be, but it's exactly what I wanted, and is still fun.  Tormented Space is torture, and though I don't play it, if you want INSANELY hard levels and a great challenge, that mode is for you.  Unfortunately I haven't beat the last level, so I don't know what Alpha Sector holds.  I would heavily recommend this game, and for $15, it's definitely worth it (or less for a Steam sale)  I'd explain more, but the experience is for you to check out personally.
