Posted: September 3, 2016
												One of my all time favourite games. Probably the most original and replayable tower defense out there. Single player it can stand tall together with strategy games like starcraft or age of empires without shame. 100% achievments took me 450 hours. I suppose it can be done in half that time. There are tons more content even after the achievements. The biggest problem is probably how the ruleset is almost identical on every map.Suggestions for the creator. Multplayer: Allow comments on map. Notify players when their map has a comment or time is beaten. Notify players when their time is beaten. List maps with newly beaten highscores. Rank players on how many 1st rank they have on maps. Chatroom? There is SO much that can be done for a competetive multiplayer scene in this game. The current DMD is pretty bare bones. Go steal some inspiration from super mario maker or similar. (How about co-op maps? Too difficult?)Map making: Ditch the obscure scripting language for javascript or similar. Allow multiple map campaigns that allows some progression. Where the outcome in one map can affect following maps. For example custom tech tree unlocked over several maps like in the original campaign. Or campaigns where the final map can be played from start, but can be made easier if you choose to beat other maps before it. Or variable prices, or unit prices or unit strength. Or pretty much anything to mix up the normal gameplay. I think this gameplay is too unique to just let it sit and spoil. Please go make a sequel. Please.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												The best game i have every played (i have about 50 hours in this game out side of steam) 1000000000000000000/10I would recommened it no matter the person even if you hate video games or have never played one yet (but play creeper world 3 abraxis or the demo first so you are familiar with the machanics)The actual review:Story: This game takes place 5 billion years after CR2, that's all the story for now because i don't want to spoil things.Gameplay: Every level except for the 2 systems leading to Prospector and Tormented zone, and the system which has Farbor in it introduces new mechanics. Such as Vapen which gives you your final command node, or Arca which gives you Thor. The gameplay is mainly build weapons to fight off various enemies and advance.The enemies are runners, spores, and the creeper. In addition to this you also have digitalists which can transport creeper over terrain instead of the creeper having to flow over. Many levels will introduce a new mechanic whether it's a permament enmy, a new tech, or a custom enemy, such as Ormos which has no emmiters, but creeper stuck in space and will come down once you land. Also on Ormos you get Terps whichcan terrraform the land. The terrian is in 10 levels. 1 being the lowest and 10 the highest, the previously mentioned digitalists can ignore this boundary and can jump terrain even if the emmiter strengh is at 3 (yes in the main campgain there are emmiters that emits 3 creeper every five seconds). You paint the terrian with whatever level you want it to be and the terps will slowly work on it. This can be sped up by a powerzone. The terps reqiure energy and the area they are terraforming cannot be covered with creeper. The powerzone enhanch all of your units abilities such as being able to make terps work faster and have a longer range or turning the motor into a fast firing, long range beast. The creeper is like CR1 so nothing to say there. However, the runners must be connected to digitalis to spawn and to survive. The runners will come out of runner nests and will stun your units, the best unit to kill them are snipers. The spores are like the ones in CR1 and CR2 they must be killed by beams and will drop a payload of creeper if not destroyed. The AE fields prevent your air units (guppys, bombers, and strafers) from flying over them. Your air units are guppys, bombers, and strafers. Guppys will transport  packets to your units such as AC, energy, or ore. Bombers use AC to spray down AC on an area and are the most powerful air unit. Strafers use energy and are essentually fighters. AC is short for anti-creeper and is gained from ore which comes from ore mines which can only be played on special spots or else you would win every mission too easily. There are 2 AC units, sprayers and bombers. Sprayers will spray AC that automatically fights creeper. It works like the AC from CR2 and it will protect your units if creeper hits them meaning that reactors will be safe if ac is on them. The main units are collecters, relays, reactors, blasters, motars, and nufflifiers. Collecters, will give you some energy and will expand you energy network, place these as far away from each other as possible since the energy production doesn't stack (they collect energy from an area like the ones from CR1). Reactors can be and should be placed in tight packs since they always give .4 energy, that can upgraded in the forge or using power nodes. Blasters have to have a line of sight and fire fast. Motars don't have to have a line of sight. Nuffelers can destory emmiters. The forge can upgrade things such as packet  speed, energy effifency, or weapon range (and yes move speed does apply to guppy's).  This review is getting very long and i covered most of the things i wanted to covers so now onto bugs.If you bugs in this game record a video, upload it to youtube, and send me the link.Oh and this game has maybe 30 story levels, 30-100 alpha levels (levels that were made in the alpha) a random generator, close to a thousand user-made maps some of which allow you to play as the creeper, and 2 areas with thousands of levels which add a new mechanic in addition to the regular stuff and an extra credits mission which turns it into a third person shooter so maybe 10 or infinity hours of content for you to play until you get bored

Posted: February 16, 2016
												This game is wonderful. I bought it a long time ago and thought I'd try it out yesterday. My goodness, this is an amazing game. I've only cleared 3 star systems, but I have thoroughly enjoyed how this game had me looking at my clock, realizing I have work to do, but still wanted to complete "one more level."This game combines tower defense mechanics and your traditional real time strategy games where you are on the frontal assault. You create power systems, linked together a supply grid you create, adding weapons structures and such to fight back the creeping enetity, creeper. It combines wonderful elements of strategic challenge and planning, since the creeper is constantly spreading toward you and your base, you often have to act fast to set up power facillities and defenses before you can press forward. I haven't found it terribly difficult so far. I have a habit of using more energy than I can produce before I spam reactors (need to work on that). I enjoy how each level throws new mechanics to aid and threaten you further. But otherwise, this game has been a wonderful rentry for me into a genre (RTS) I have driffted away from over the years.10/10 would have my base blown up by spores again.

Posted: August 10, 2016
One of the best strategy games on SteamMany survival/strategy games are like drowning. Such games play out as a constant desperate struggle to stay above water, with no chance to breathe, until you are eventually overwhelmed and die a horrible death.Creeper World 3 is more like walking a tight-rope. At any time you can pause, catch your breath, and steady yourself for the next step. The risk is when you start moving. It is always a delicate balance - if you go too fast and overextend yourself, you will lose ground instead of gaining it. This is strategy at its best.If drowning sounds like more fun, don't play this game - it isn't for you.The diverse selection of units - each with its own distinct role - enables several rewarding strategies. The level terrain and enemy placement strongly impact tactics, so every mission feels distinct.The game includes more missions than you will ever play, a level editor for making even more missions and sharing with the community, and an option for procedurally-generated levels as well. You will never run out of content.Creeper World 3 features satisfying and refreshing mechanics you will find in no other game. My first experience with it was overwhelmingly enjoyable. As I mastered the mechanics, it felt less novel but no less satisfying. Years later, I still dedicate time every month to purging more creeper.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Ok. Creeper World 3 is an amazing RTS. You need to build your base, collect resources and build defences to protect yourself against the overwhelming enemy that quickly grows in power and takes over the whole map. When you grow strong enough, you start pushing back, shooting your way through the enemy forces. You need to make sure that your assault is well covered, is connected to the supply line and that you won't run out of resources at a critical moment. You shoot down air units and lauch air assaults and bombarding deep in enemy territory. Oh, and NEVER forget about defending your land. A small mistake can be enough to screw up your plans.It's extremely satisfying when you capture land and push further into the enemy territory, and destroy they structures. The game combines moments of despair, heroism and triumph. But there's one important detail.You don't fight humans, but blue alien mass that spreads extremely fast and destroys everything in it's path. But despite this you still feel like you fight a war against a much stronger enemy.The amount of different things you need to keep track off, the gameplay focused on tactical planning, the awesome music that's both dramatic and badass...Oh, and did I mention the crazy amount of content? There are thousands of maps you can fight on in the official campaigns, and there's also a level editor and a random level generator.In short: great RTS with a truckload of content. Buy it now.

I'm not really into the story, but it seems some kind of (underground?) monster has some arses in planets and from those asses, it is spreading some kind of liquid. Physics make sure that these fluids flow and spread over your planet, destroying everything that is not planet, wall or enemy on its way. Posted: June 16, 2015
												Review written after 10 hours of play.  Summary, well executed, fun and satisfying game but turn the volume down.  Interesting RTS that doesn't follow the usual formula.  You are fighting against a rising liquid tide and have to plug your defenses then expand outward.  Has a simple yet effective art style that conveys all the information you need.  Playstyle is reminiscent of tower defense but more immediate, at the same time levels can often feel like a puzzle.  This combination means finishing a level is usually very satisfying.  The game does an excellent job of gradually introducing the mechanics and units and the levels where they are introduced do a good job of teaching you how to use them effectively without holding your hand.  The creep behaves intuitively leading to emergent strategies that the game never outright tells you about but make perfect sense, particularly as regards the terraforiming.  You can make walls and trenches to control the flow of the creep, or push back an area then build walls around it to expand into a large pool.  So far the levels have been varied enough that each new level has made me think 'ah interesting, how am I going to deal with this?'    About the only negative I've found is that the sound design.  Weapon sound effects can be very repetitive, especially when you are in the late stages of a level and have many mortars and strafers firing at once.  Also the music while by no means bad is very penetrating and booming and combined with the sound effects can be extremely irritating for other people in the house who aren't playing the game.   Easily sorted by turning the volume down and the games other qualities make this a relatively minor grumble.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												Argh...its like crack, I tell you now - stay away!In all seriousness, its very engaging in many ways. To me, it is the logistics of war, abstracted into a fight against the "grey goo" of science fiction. You begin by dropping on-planet, setting up energy collectors and ore mines, and trying to stay one step ahead of the goo by running relay lines (think high-voltage lines) to power the various weapon systems you'll need to fight it. Cannons, mortars, sprayers, and other tools are at your disposal. Interestingly, you are able to reposition them as the situation on the ground changes. From there, it is a systematic war of resources and logistics to reach the Emitters that produce the Creeper/Goo. You then build a nullifier which charges up and fires a high-powered beam into the emitter, destroying it.I'll be the first to admit I haven't made it far yet. Two hours in, and several missions in the story mode. I love every useful goodie I find on planets and put to use as I go. I'm sure there are many others out there to find. Icing on the cake to me. It's fun without being overly complex, and very easy to get caught up in the deadly "just one more turn" syndrome.For two bucks, hours of fun. Grab it and give it a try...if you dare! *Muahahahah!*

												I have personay put hundreds of hours into the three free flash based games, and I loved them all. I saw this game on steam and had to have it. Posted: July 12, 2015
												You can check this out in video form here: 


YouTube™ Video: Game Spotlight: Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal 

			Views: 977		

			Creeper World 3 is what happens when cellular automata takes over a strategy simulation. Instead of discreet units that attack your base, a fluid-like substance spreads over the terraformable...		

Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal is a fluid time strategy game,that is a game where you can pause and even speed up the time, just like in city builder games.Creeper World 3 focuses heavily on base building. All buldings need to be connected to a resource network and many of the buildings can be moved in a way similar to the Terran buildings in StarCraft. The main enemy is the creeper, which is a fluid flowing out of emitters.This fluid will flow downhill which is usually towards you. You cannot build in creeper and it destroys your buildings if it touches them.The maps have 10 height levels and you can build terraformers to change the terrain gradually. This gives you tons of tactical options. The simplest example would be to build yourself a high wall as protection against the creeper. Beware that creeper levels accumulate and if you do not destroy some, it will flow over your precious walls.You have various guns and mortars in your arsenal to destroy the creeper and you can even deploy your own anti-creeper, but this is just pushing back against the endless flow. To stop new creeper from forming, you need to push towards the emitter and build a special building, the nullifier, and protect it until it powers up enough to destroy the emitter.There are other interesting foes and obstacles, which I will not spoil here. The bread and butter of the enemy is the creeper emitter. Most of the tension for me was usually in the early game, where I needed to stave off the creeper while building my resource economy and it's often about eeking out tiny little advantages until I could stably match the creeper. After that, the aggressive phase starts. There are dozens of interesting story missions with diverse leveldesigns where you need different strategies to win.After beating the story missions, which took me about 30 hours!, you have a sheer endless supply of challenge maps, as well as tons of user generated maps. Though I find that the challenge maps aren't as diverse as the story maps, so once you find your dominant strategy, they tend to play out similarly. Creeper World 3 is also an excellent podcast game, since all relevant information is presented visually.The game gets a clear purchase recommendation from me.You can play the demo version beforehand, you can find that on the developer's website.Creeper World 3 has a crazy high rating of 97% on Steam, which I think is because the Trailer shows you exactly what you can expect from the game.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												It is vaguely tower defense...  you cannot control the path of your enemies with your towers, nor does your enemy have a path at all.  Your enemy is "creeper" - an obvious ripoff in name and behavior of Starcraft's creep.  It is goo which expands from a central point.  The goo will destroy your towers so you must keep it at bay.  The whole game is about first protecting your base from the goo then slowly pushing the goo back until you destroy the enemy target.  The graphics are a la 1989.  The gameplay is simplistic.  There is a lot of content, though.  If you are tolerant of poor graphics and this style of game sounds interesting, then it'll keep you occupied for a decent period of time for a low price.  I found it underwhelming, possibly because I like the more traditional tower defense, but I have played it a lot.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Talk about addictive...Haven't played a "just 5 more minutes" game since Dune II (or Master of Orion II but that was turn based and a completely other kind of game). This game has a lot of resemblance with Dune.Lots of people tag it as tower defense but I don't really agree. For starters, you are the attacker and there really aren't towers. But most of all, tower defense is about repetitiveness, about more and more units attacking in the same way, where this game, also predictable because of its nature with physics, has a much more broad attack style.So what's it about? I'm not really into the story, but it seems some kind of (underground?) monster has some arses in planets and from those asses, it is spreading some kind of liquid. Physics make sure that these fluids flow and spread over your planet, destroying everything that is not planet, wall or enemy on its way. Your weapon against this fluid is some kind of weapon drying it out. Well, not one kind, there are a lot of types and they all have their advantages and disadvantages. It's your job to eradicate these squirters from these world, making sure life can start again on those planets, although some planets have gone too far for this and are only to be cleared of the monster for the technology that is left behind there.This game is terribly addictive. I have played it a lot offline first (bought it through their website to have it DRM free) and activated it with a key on steam.

Posted: July 11, 2015
												I have personay put hundreds of hours into the three free flash based games, and I loved them all. I saw this game on steam and had to have it. This is a unique kind of tower defense (TD) game, with a much more organic feeling enemy than 'I just follow these paths regardless of the danger to my health.' That single change from the normal TD lets this game have so much more complex and involved levels. The towers range from simple towers like the blaster and mortar, to more complex ones such as the strafer and the XL cannon you get later in the campaign (Called Thors Hammer, if I recall correctly). Posted: June 18, 2015
												The third game in the fantastic creeper world series. It takes the gameplay of the original, and builds on it; interestingly, it gives you all of your old toys pretty quickly. The anti-creeper from the sequel makes a return, and works quite well. The level design was decent, although there were times when I felt it could've used work, and I rarely found it necessary to use more than one control node, with the exception of the timed missions.The story was the weakest part, having reduced the cast to just two members: Abraxis and his ship's AI. There's some good world building, but I think it could've been greatly expanded upon, and the twist ending was really unexpected, and felt out of place. I'm not fond of stories that retcon their own history. If you want a great story, I'd recommend playing the original, which is still the best in this regard.I was honestly hoping for a longer experience overall, but there is replay value in the form of custom community maps (still haven't tried it yet), as well as a random map generator which need to be unlocked through the campaign. Something I'd love to see is a massive map, spanning several screens in size, with complex terrain and hidden secrets buried around the map; the only time you excavate anything in game is during the last level.On the whole, fans of the genre will enjoy this, just don't expect any literary awards. 8/10.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												An awesome game for fans of defense, strategy, and single-player RTS games.  Near infinite replayability beyond the campaign levels with extra-hard levels/custom-created maps (the game has its own scripting language that diehard fans are exploring tremendously).Pros:-The liquid-based enemy of the Creeper is totally unique-Satisfying "combat" and a real feeling of accomplishment that is visually rewarded when overcoming an obstacle (Your energy grid and supply lines grant amazing visual feedback)-Surprisingly deep decision making for some of the harder maps, but everything is always fair - no cheap shots or surprises-Play at your own pace, pausing to build or plan ahead, and saving/loading whenever you want (You can play a mission slowly and safely and eventually overcome anything, or push yourself to the limit and try to beat them even faster or more efficiently)-Low cost for the amount of replayability offered-Highly customizable - Sound, controls, visibility/colors of elements on the game screenCons:-There's a definite learning curve beyond the main missions that may seem off-putting at first - complexity of units, resources, mechanics, terminology-Fans of defense games with direct player combat/intervention (FPS controls or special abilities) may not like the nearly fully automated weapons/enemy-The art style is a bit simplistic, even if you're a fan of pixel art-y or tiny models, and can cause the visuals to blend together for new players-Some of the sound design can get repetitive, especially when you've got large scale bases and battles

Posted: August 11, 2015
												Creeper World 3 is very similar to Creeper World 1. For those who haven't played Creeper World 1:You need to build and defend a little city from a relentless flow of blue goo whose physics behaves like water. You can vaporize it with lasers, blow it up with mortars, hit it with air strikes, and even terraform the landscape to trap it--for a while. The catch is that all of these things require energy, and you've got to find a balance between building up your energy supply while also building up your defenses. If you don't have enough of one or the other, the never-ending flow of creeper will slowly overwhelm your city. It's an excellent strategy game that combines defensive thinking and resource management.For those who have played CW1:This is mostly the same game, but with a story-mode and plenty of new levels. There's also a few new toys to play with, like ways to generate your own "anti-creeper," ways to terraform the terrain, and even ways to fly energy packets to remote areas that are not connected to your network. The creeper also has a few new tricks including "digitalis" which spreads faster and is harder to destroy but is limited to pre-defined paths, and "runners" which are little mobs that can temporarily disable your structures. I could knock the game for not being more innovative, but I liked CW1 enough that I thoroughly enjoyed having a similar experience again.

												Creeper World might have the least appealing trailer ever; the presentation is unrefined at best.  Hoever, this is a true diamond in the rough.  Based on other reviews, it sounds like most folks share my opinion.  This game takes the best parts of the tower defence, real time strategy, and sim games and remixes them into something greater than the sum of its parts.  Throw an engaging narrative on top of that, and I am a happy gamer.  If you really aren't sure whether this game is for you, check out the online version... it started as a freely distributed browser game, and several early versions are still out there.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												If you are new to the game, go and play the first one NOW. If you think that you liked that game then buy this one. This game is a huge improvement to the entire series with many more weapons, buildings and even more bases! You will fight your way through many different worlds taking advantage of the terrain and different power-ups found of left by the creeper you have obliterated. You could go in head-first and attempt to destroy the creeper or you could wait until you have the resources for a swift and quick victory. How you play is your choice.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Tedious as all hell- but this is done to proper regards. It's a  game of sorts where your enemy isn't distinct units, but fluid. A full-out RTS of this series would be nifty. Or some form of PVP.Starts off deceptively simple; but you'll know when♥♥♥♥♥♥s about to get real.

Posted: December 3, 2016
												Pretty neat game. I first found it as a flash game a few years back, then a while ago I found the flash game again and though, man this would be a cool full game. A quick search on steam revealed that it was!The gameplay of this game is simple, your enemy works exactly like water and will flow out across the landscape dropping into and quickly filling up holes, or build up so much to climb up to higher levels. Your job is to create a defence that blasts back the "creeper" until you can get close enough to destroy the source.With a campaign, different modes, and a user created content section, this game has infinite playability, and I found to be a ton of fun, even though sometimes a single level would take me 3 hours (I like to play really conservatively) I found the game to be a ton of fun, with little to no issues I could find. I would definitely recommend.

Posted: January 2
												A truly unique game.  I've had this game on my radar since it was on a flash sale summer 2015. Decided not to buy it, because it looked a little too complex. After that the price became never that low again. Dispite that I recently bought the game.I'm having alot of fun! Posted: January 2
												If the idea of high res eye candy is a requirement for you, do not get this game. However if gameplay and mechanics are important, (like they are for me,) this is a great strategy game.The campaign will take you a few days to get through (depending on how much time you devote to it each day.) However, there is so much content available through additional "official" scenarios and fan made maps (there is an editor) that you will not have time to ever look at all of them, let alone play them all. (and most that I have played are quite good.)Right now, the spiritual successor, Particle Fleet: Emergence is also available on steam. While having similar concepts there are plenty of differences. I would suggest getting both. Both games are very good in their own right, if you like one, you will like the other... and different enough to justify having both.

Posted: February 8
												At first look I thought this game was a simplistic strategy game with some Tower Defense elements. It doesn't have flashy graphics, nor is it a multiplayer game,but what it does, it does really, really well. I've sunk countless hours into this and enjoyed all of it. If you like a little solid Tower Defense title, this is a gem. I, for one, reccommend it.

Posted: February 4
												This game is on my all-time favorites list. I've been heavily, heavily invested in this series since 2009 with the first game, and it got better with every installment. I'd have to say this one is my favorite, def. Playtime is at most a third of my actual playtime since I got this game before it was on steam. The story is so good as the close for the three-game epic through the  entirety of the human race. You really need to play the first two games, esp the initial one, to really appreciate the progression for the protagonist, but the gameplay gives it an excellent stand-alone experience. Bless Knuckle Cracker. Please play this game.

Posted: February 5
												I dislike these type of pixle games and purchased this game only because of its high rating, despite being burnt for doing the same thing multiple times before.It was a worth while risk and I am still happy with the chance I took with this game.It didn't look much like a 'story' based game but the tale it told was mature, engaging, and well paced.The gameplay would normally be repetative in this type of game however it managed to avoid multiple pitfalls.There is enough challenge where I failed around 40% of missions but never felt frustrated, surprisingly enough.There are a lot of extras after completing the main game which I still play sporadically.I don't think I will ever replay the whole campain again but I would still enjoy it if I did replay it.My personal "Top 10 Hidden Gems of all time"

Posted: February 15
												An excellent game with nicely paced progression.You'll rage during some levels but once you complete it you'll realize it wasn't hard at all.The game forces you to try new strategies and use all your capabilites - no one approach beats all levels.Recommended.

Posted: January 25
												I first heard about this series by playing the free demos of the first and second one online. I enjoyed them for a long time, and eventually found that this was at the time the only full game on steam. I hadn't bought any of the full games yet so I didn't know the immensity of the game. Although story mode is small but interesting, the rest of the game contains an unfathomable amount of levels, along with the ability to play levels made by yourself and others online. The levels can range from easy or challenging, and this game is more fun if you enjoy having to meticulously fight back agains the opposing creeper and plan your infrastructure. The soundtrack has only 2 songs that play during levels, but they are substantial enought that you will never get tired of them. The story is a little hard to understand because I didn't play the first 2, but the ridiculously large years (evidentally this is trillions of years in the future if not more) make it hard to fathom the amount of time passed, wich is kind of cool.TL:DR Creeper World is a great game that provides countless hours of engaging playtime.

Posted: January 17
												The game is based on a mechanic that invents a completely new "enemy" on the tower defense or RTS genre. The enemy is a liquid that you have to fight back and survive. I love the series and have played through all of the entries. But to be honest, Creeper World 3 was... a disappointment. This one I like the least in the series. I suppose my problem here is lack of innovation. I felt like there was nothing new to the game compared to the old ones. I think I was already waiting for something new but all I got was second base and improved graphics. Even the engine is the same. I feel like I still want to see one more game from the series. But with added content. Not just million maps that in the end, after a few games, are all the same. I want more mechanics, maybe different types of Creeper, more tech, more weapons, maybe upgrades for the weapons, "smart" creeper that activly tries to fight back with different mechanics and weapons and not just flop the predictable way where the game stays hours in a stale mate, and more!I recommend the game but I find the older ones to be more intresting

Posted: February 2
												First off let me tell you that I love this games concept.  the turret deffense along with leaderboards and other things make for a rather interesting game.some key things I have to dissagree with on the concepts.1) leaderboards are broken.  how can you beat a level in less than a min.  it takes more time for your orbitals to land than some of these people took to beat the levels.  I call foul.2) Campaign - It seems choppy at best, and broken as worst.  sure I was able to beat it.  but most of the items you have at your disposal and the fact that even two ore harvesters cannot support one single ore spitter for continuious fire is sad.  then there are the titans.  Useless in ever case.  even on the missions you may want them they take too long to fire, the creep comes back too fast even on 1x speed to do anything tactical with them, and the last one is only for the end mission, you don't even get to use it on special missions after you unlock it.now for the reason that this game is great!1) it has user/mod like interface.  looks to me (haven't finnished all bonus sectors yet) that you get to make and share with other players in these maps.  maybe they just modify/test them first to make sure you don't screw over the comunity, but this is a rather interesting idea.2) the story is actually decent.  Sure it may seem obvious at times, and others down right boring.  However, if you decide to read it all (storyline) you get an interesting story.  one worth talking about to friends and family.  Just like when you read a good book, or new article.3) Replayability - Sure the leaderboards are broken, but you can still post your times and strive to improve them, come up with new and interesting ideas on how to beat the levels, and even strive to limit yourself in ways not ment (like only cannons and solor collectors)In the end this game is worth picking up, yet I would think nothing more than $10 for the short campaign limit, but the extra sectors do make up for the loss in gameplay.  Just wish they had some kind of RPG element sector where you gather things/currency and use them to improve/unlock different items to use in the next mission (like if you could boost yourself with a starting ammount of energy or something)  of course this would destroy the leaderboards in that sector, but that would be something like score rather than just time (like -points per sec and +points for builds and kills.  Also give you a point handycap for bonuses, and a point bonus for detriments)Anyways if you like Tower Defense or base building you may want to check this game out.
